dataset.title: Data used for Figure 3 of the Nature Reviews Earth and Environment (NREE) paper: "A low-to-no snow future and its impacts on water resources in the western United States

associatedParty.organizationName: U.S. DOE > Office of Science > Biological and Environmental Research (BER)

abstract.para: In order to synthesize western United States snowpack projections, this dataset contains the results of 18 peer-review journal articles over three periods of interest (2025-2049, 2050-2074, and 2075-2099) and over 4 mountain ranges (Cascades, Sierra Nevada, Rockies, Wasatch/Uinta) in addition to western-US wide projections. Distinction is made by model type (Earth System Models, bias-corrected statistically downscaled Earth System Models, and regional climate models). RCP4.5 and RCP8.5 emission scenarios are considered. Percent snow water equivalent (SWE) loss considers 1 April, peak SWE and/or seasonal SWE. Heterogeneity in projected snowpack changes exists across mountain ranges and for different modeling approaches, but generally indicate agreement in decreases by the end of the century.

section.title: Related References
section.para: Siirila-Woodburn, E.R., Rhoades, A.M., Hatchett, B.J. et al. A low-to-no snow future and its impacts on water resources in the western United States. Nat Rev Earth Environ 2, 800–819 (2021). https://doi.org/10.1038/s43017-021-00219-y
Additional metadata on specific locations within the watershed are provided in the following related data package:

Varadharajan C ; Kakalia Z ; Burrus M ; O'Ryan D ; Alper E ; Banfield J ; Berkelhammer M ; Beutler C ; Brodie E ; Brown W ; Carbone M S ; Carroll R ; Christianson D ; Chou C ; Crystal-Ornelas R ; Chadwick K D ; Christensen J ; Dafflon B ; Elbashandy H ; Enquist B J ; Fox P ; Gochis D ; Henderson M ; Johnson D ; Kueppers L ; Matheus Carnevali P ; Newman A ; Powell T ; Singha K ; Sorensen P ; Sprenger M ; Tokunaga T ; Versteeg R ; Wilkins M ; Williams K ; Worsham M ; Wong C ; Wu Y ; Agarwal D (2022): Location Identifiers, Metadata, and Map for Field Measurements at the East River Watershed, Colorado, USA (Version 3.0). Watershed Function SFA, ESS-DIVE repository. Dataset. doi:10.15485/1660962

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: The East River (ER) is a snow‐dominated, headwater basin of the Upper Colorado River Basin (UCRB) located in the western United States. The ER is the designated testbed of Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory's Watershed Function Scientific Focus Area (WFSFA). Through WFSFA, observational networks have been established to measure stream discharge and precipitation chemistry. The ER is considered representative of many snow‐dominated headwaters of the Rocky Mountains. The study domain encompasses nearly 85 square km, a 1.4‐km vertical drop in elevation (4,120 to 2,760 m) and pristine alpine, subalpine, montane, and riparian ecosystems. The ER contains high‐energy mountain streams to low‐energy meandering floodplains and is eroding primarily into the Cretaceous, carbon‐rich, marine shale of the Mancos Formation. Additional metadata on specific locations within the watershed are provided in the following related data package: Varadharajan C. et al. (2022) doi:10.15485/1660962

description.para: In order to synthesize the snowpack literature from Supplemental Table 1 and present the findings in Fig. 3 a few assumptions had to be made, described here for reproducibility purposes. First studies were chosen that provide snow projections using, at least, one emissions scenario. If possible, RCP4.5, a low-emissions scenario, or, more commonly, RCP8.5, a high-emissions scenario. The study must evaluate snow projections with snow metrics which describe April 1st, peak SWE, and/or seasonal SWE changes. The study also needs to be conducted over the entire WUS and/or for individual mountain ranges in the WUS such as the Cascades, Sierra Nevada, Rockies, and Wasatch and Uinta. Studies are not included if they have less-than five continuous years, nor if the study is primarily focused on a historical time period. Percentage SWE changes are directly recorded in Supplemental Table 2. If SWE changes were provided as absolute values they are cast into a percentage of SWE change relative to their historical base-period. The SWE changes are binned within three 25-year time periods (2025-2049, 2050-2074, and 2075-2100). If the time periods analyzed in a particular study overlap between two of the 25-year time periods, they are binned into the time period that has the most number of years over which the projection was conducted. A range of percent SWE changes are also included if a study split certain mountain ranges into two or more segments or if multiple models are presented and evaluated independently within the study. If a considerable number of simulations are presented in a study, a range of SWE loss is taken (max and min change) and then the median of those changes is used in Fig. 3. Last, SWE changes are sometimes presented directly in sections and/or tables, but were more often presented within xy- and/or time-series plots. To extract SWE changes from these figures a free-ware software is used (https://apps.automeris.io/wpd/). The sections, tables and figures that were used to extract SWE changes have been explicitly mentioned in Supplemental Table 2.
